bibl.title: Letter from H. Carter Redd to Philip Showalter Hench, January 26, 1948

div1.p: Redd describes two letters he found concerning Carter's yellow fever work, and notes that he eliminated a lot of correspondence between Carter and Redd and Carter and his lawyer. He will send Hench the material if Carter's son approves.

div1.head: Letter from H. Carter Redd to Philip Showalter Hench, January 26, 1948
div1.opener:
Commissioner of Accounts and Commissioner in
Chancery of Circuit Court of Hanover County
H. CARTER REDD
ATTORNEY-AT-LAW
1104 TRAVELERS BUILDING
RICHMOND, VA.
January 26th, 1948
Dr. Philip S. Hench
Mayo Clinic
Rochester, Minnesota
My dear Doctor:
div1.p:
I have not heard from Dr. Carter in regard to sending
you the mass of correspondence etc. in the trunks belonging
to Dr. Carter's father.

I spent yesterday evening going through one of the
packages and ran across two letters, copies of which I am
sending you herein; the one to Dr. Bruce is in accord with what
I had understood, that is, that Dr. Carter and Dr. Reed were
working together, endeavoring to find the cause of yellow fever
and Dr. Carter was taken off of the work and put in charge of
the epidemic which had broken out while Dr. Reed continued with
the experiments which they had outlined. The experiments,
or rather research, was in pursuance of the data which my
uncle had gathered.

In going over the papers, I eliminated a lot of
correspondence had between Dr. Carter and myself and Dr.
Carter and James Martin a lawyer in Norfolk, which would
have been of no use to you and would have been a burden on
you to go over it. A great deal of the correspondence and
letters are in regard to malaria, Dengue and plague as well
as yellow fever.

If Dr. Carter of Birmingham will allow me, I will
be glad to send you all of this material as there are some
references to Walter Reed in this.
div1.closer: Very truly yours, H. Carter Redd HCR:jh
